body:
pls post

pd.show_versions()
df.info()
ptdump -av file

show your writing and reading code exactly
10 bucks says it's a scoping issue

Phillip: thanks for your input - did you mean a scoping issue within pandas or did you mean with something on my end? It's quite straightforward how I've applied it.
No I mean within pandas.
I can't see anything from a cursory glance. I'll take a deeper look tomorrow.

## Here's how I read in the table:

``` python
df = DataFrame()
store = pd.HDFStore('/Users/neil/MKT.h5')
df = store.select('MKT', "(a > 10) & (b > 1)")
store.close()
```

## Here's how I write/fill the table:

``` python
store = pd.HDFStore('/Users/neil/MKT.h5')

listofsearchablevars = ['date', 'text', 'a', 'x20', 'x23', 'x24', 'b', 'x25', 'x26', 'x35', 'x36', 'x37', 'x38', 'x39', 'x40', 'x41', 'x42']

df = .....

store.append('MKT', df, data_columns = listofsearchablevars, nan_rep = 'nan', chunksize=500000, min_itemsize = {'values': 30})

store.close()
```
Thanks Phillip, I really appreciate the help.  I'm just totally puzzled.
can u show a sample of a, b for the 15k rows and then show a,b for a row that is in the. 3 0 k but not in the 15k
@nmvasani is there anyway you can drop the data somewhere and i can take a look at it?
@nmvasani you are going to have to provide the file via  link.
you are showing a transformed view which is useless, dtype information has been erased (its all object) by definition.

strip everything out of your file excluding a/b and a single data field (that is not a data_column). see if the error persists. if it does then put a link to this file up (or you can just put a link to the file).

@cpcloud Phillip, the file is 1.66 GB in size - it's huge....not sure about putting it up in the public domain.
@jreback my apologies if I've inadvertently diminished the usefulness of what I've provided here by providing the sample data in such a way....I'm trying my best! I'm somewhat of a novice and trying to respond as best as I can to help fix this problem (I care about Pandas a lot!).  How would you suggest, or what else should I provide?  I just saw your recent post on stripping out everything except a & b and one more data field that's not a data_column.  I'll try that now and report back.

their is most prob some value or some interaction in the query. see if you can progressively reduce the file (and keep reproducing the error). start by stripping everything extraneous out as I suggest.
@jreback ok thanks, will do and will report back.
@jreback to better understand your diagnosis - what do you mean about "their is most prob some value or some interaction in the query"

here's an example of a problem that DID occurr.

if the queried table had a `nan` in the 0th position it would fail, but any other position would succeed for something like 'a > 0' where a was a float column. (this is fixed in PyTables >= 3.1). but its an example of where their could be an actual bug (in pandas or the underlying library). or could be an incorrect dtype or something else.

As I said, try to progressiviely narrow down the file so  your error reproduces. Its easier to find that way.
@jreback got it, thanks for the clarification.  I'm stripping it down now.  I'll look at 0th position or similar to see if there's something insightful or the sorts to report back.

SUCESS!!!!! I filled all NaNs in the data and now the read_hdf where returns the correct 30,000 rows.  column a had NaNs (which was one of the data_columns in the query, a > 10).  Man, that was painful.  FYI - because of my paranoia, to get rid of any possible circumstance that this could repeat itself in the future, I completely fillna(0) the entire table as I cannot risk reaching conclusions from this analysis with an incorrect or incomplete query from the table.  It was a NaN issue for sure.
can u repro the error w/o filling the Nan's?
let me try....
Yes, the problem is reproduced without filling in the NaNs.  Confirmed

ok can u post something that reproduces then?
(a file link is ok)

trying to see what kind of issue this is
not sure what you mean...do you mean the hdf5 file with the 1.66GB of data?
yes, whatever you have is fine. I am trying to see if this is a pervasive error.

Yup, I understand - it's essential to figure out if it's a pervasive error or not, else this problem solving  exercise may be less meaningful.  Let me see what I can do - I need to think/check is this dataset can be put up in the public domain as well.
you can also send me a private link if you want   jeff.reback@gmail.com

Ok great, many thanks Jeff, and thank you for your guidance and evaluation here - it's sincerely appreciated.  I may need to chat with some other folks and I'm contending with public holidays here.  I'll try my best and understand we could learn a lot more and save other from experiencing problem such as these if we can have this file/dataset examined a little closer.
